children: A 47-year-old man develops skin pain, gritty eyes, oral lesions, and odynophagia 2 weeks after a course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The skin findings of TEN are painful, flat, purpuric, targetoid lesions that coalesce into dusky, poorly demarcated, confluent patches or may consist of confluent, tender erythema without identifiable individual lesions. The involved epidermis blisters and sloughs in sheets of skin, leaving behind denuded dermis. This image shows the erythema, sloughing skin, and a small area of denuded dermis next to the gluteal cleft.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is usually associated with more intense erythema than is seen in this image, but may have skin sloughing as well. Toxic shock syndrome has more limited skin findings, most frequently erythema and subsequent desquamation of the palms and soles.
